Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my heart pounding. Just minutes ago, I’d learned that a careless joke I made last night had really hurt my friend, Ahmed. He hadn’t said anything at the time, but now I’d heard from his brother that Ahmed was devastated. As his friend, I knew I needed to call him right away, to apologize, to explain myself, to try to fix what I’d broken. That’s what friends do—communicate, clear the air, make things right before wounds fester.

But as I stood in the mosque office, the clock ticked closer to Jummah. I was the imam, and the congregation was gathering. I was expected to deliver the sermon, to guide and inspire, to be present and focused. The guest speaker was ready, but I’d promised the community I would speak today. They looked to me for leadership, for stability, especially in these uncertain times.

My phone buzzed in my hand. I could picture Ahmed waiting, hurting, maybe hoping I’d reach out. I could also hear the growing murmur of the congregation, waiting for me to step up. My chest tightened as I weighed the demands of friendship against the expectations of my role as imam, torn between two worlds that both needed me, right now.
